discussion.content:
long distance vmotion require: enterprise plus license, round trip ttl below 150ms
recommended: separate ip stack (on esx) for network isolation.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator needs to migrate VMs in the same vCenter from New York to California due to impending severe weather.
Which migration should the administrator perform without causing VM downtime?

choices.D: VMware vSphere Storage APIs Array Integration (VAAI)
choices.C: VMware vStorage APIs for Data Protection (VADP)

questions.question_text: Which vSphere APIs support storage hardware acceleration?

A vSphere administrator discovers the size of the .vswp file for a VM with 2 vCPUs and 4GB of memory is zero.
What could be the cause?

choices.D: VM is in a suspended state.
choices.C: VM is running on a snapshot.

questions.answer_description: swap file = configured memory "" memory reservation

discussion.content: swap file = configured memory MINUS memory reservation

questions.question_text: Which action should be taken to secure ISCSI devices in a vSphere environment?

choices.D: Require ESXi hosts to authentication to the target.
choices.B: Require ESXi hosts to use ISCSI port binding.

discussion.content:
To secure iSCSI devices, require that the ESXi host, or initiator, can authenticate to the iSCSI device, or target, whenever the host attempts to access data on the target LUN.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-DFC745FB-CDD6-4828-8948-4D0E0561EEF8.html

D is Correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-DFC745FB-CDD6-4828-8948-4D0E0561EEF8.html

To secure iSCSI devices, require that the ESXi host, or initiator, can authenticate to the iSCSI device, or target, whenever the host attempts to access data on the target LUN.

choices.D: Uplinks are allowed to be configured in an Active/Standby configuration.
choices.A: Data center setup and administration are simplified by centralizing network configuration.
choices.B: There is IPv6 support for a VDS.

discussion.content: B, C, and D can all be applied on a Standard Virtual Switch.
AE are right. I would say the the "Port migrates with their client" means that a vmotion to a different host doesn't change the port binding. That's why port mirroring works on the VDS only...

These options are not available on vSphere standard switches. Customers can configure the following key parameters for each dvportgroup.

Number of virtual ports (dvports)
Port binding (static, dynamic, ephemeral)
VLAN Trunking/Private VLANs
Teaming and Load Balancing along with Active and Standby Links
Bi-directional traffic shaping parameters
Port Security

https://blogs.vmware.com/vsphere/2011/11/vds-best-practices-virtual-and-physical-switch-parameters.html

comments.content: Teaming and Load Balancing along with Active and Standby Links are avilable on standard switches. The blog is wrong or outdated.

discussion.content:
A is correct, VDS is configured at Datacenter level. 
B,C,D are available in VSS as well. 
E makes no sense to me, but that is the only other option left.

comments.content: E. States that the port associated with the VM migrates to the new host along with the VM. With a VSS the port binding is removed (as VSS is local to each host) and when the VM is on its new host a new port binding is created with the local VSS. As a VDS is distributed across all hosts, there is no need to remove and recreate a binding.

questions.question_text: What are two advantages of deploying a VDS as compared to a VSS? (Choose two.)
